title: Economics: Supply and Demand
blurb: Learn how supply and demand affect prices using kid-friendly examples like snacks, toys, and a lemonade stand.

vocab.definition: The study of how people make, buy, and sell goods and services
How much of a good or service is available
How much people want a good or service
When there is not enough of something to meet everyone's wants

teachingNotes: Use simple, everyday items like pencils, snacks, and toys to show how supply and demand can change prices. Connect to a classroom store or lemonade stand.

sample.question: Give an example of something kids might demand at school.
If there are many apples to sell, is supply high or low?
If many kids want the same toy, is demand high or low?
When there is not enough for everyone, what is that called?
What could make prices go down?
What could make prices go up?

truefalse.question: If many kids want a snack and there are only a few left, the price might go up.
If there are lots of stickers and few kids want them, the price might go down.
Demand means how much is available to sell.
Supply means how much people want to buy.
Scarcity means there is more than enough for everyone.
When supply is high and demand is low, prices usually go down.
When supply is low and demand is high, prices usually go up.
Price is the amount of money something costs.
If demand goes down, sellers can always raise prices.
If demand goes up, sellers might raise prices.

choices: There are many pencils to sell
